page.lettertext:
fol.118r
May it please your good L. Soe longe absence of
e Deputies
of
Guelderland,
and
Overissel,
is greatly wondred at heere:
and till all
e Deputies be mette, they can take no resolution
upon my proposition. It is feared very much that some
alteration of thinges at home hath stayed their commming,
or at
e least their present passadge: by reasons of the great
inundations in sundrie places of these
Provinces:
as the
lyke was never seene, of
e rivers and land waters in
e
memorie of any. For all
e Bettue, and Bommels wert
are overflowen, and a great parte of
e Contrie round
about
Utrecht,
and
Amersfort;
in soe muche as
e very gates
of
e towne of Amersfort, the suburbes of
Vianen,
and ma-
ny Dorpes and villages are caried cleane awaye, and mul-
titudes of people, to
e nomber, it thought, of 3000 souldes,
are drowned. And the lyke is reported of
e land about
Collen,
where the waters are risen higher by six foote,
then hath bin hitherto knowen by any recorde, which is
supposed to proceede of
e great abundance of raine and
snowe,
at hath fallen in these, and in the upper Contreis:
and of
e long continuance of this bositrous wynde at west,
which hath forced the rivers to swell out of measure.
I fynde by conferring with some of
e Scottish nation,
t
they are informed out of
Scotland,
at
Coronel Stuart
is enjoyned by some secret instruction, to sollicit
e States
for 1000 foote, and 500 horse for sixe monethes, or rather
for
e loane of soe muche mony, as may serve for the levie
of soe many men, requesting 3 monethes paye to be de-
livered out of hand, w
ch
is imparted unto me by suche
persons of credit, as I in my conceat have reason to be-
leeve it. Nevertheles the Coronel himself will not no-
tifie soe muche, not onely to me, but as farre as I per-
ceave it none of the
States:
proposing all as yet in ge-
nerall tearmes, and referring to themselves to yealde w
at
succor they thincke best, w
ch
is thought to be done upon
a hope
at he hath, that they of themselves will offer more,
then he hath in charge to presse them unto. For myne
owne part, the more
at I consider of his imploiment
hither, and of the qualitie of his message,
e more me
thinkes it doth tend, to some dessigne to be dislicked.
fol.118v
For in proceeding with these Provinces, the King hath gone
by suche degrees, to winne upon their amitie, as I feare
somewhat els then this purpose pretended of joining in
alliance and of craving their assistance.
If your L. calle to mynde, in Fe
b
laste was two yeares,
the States were moved by Stuart, beyng sent by
e King,
to intertaine from tyme to time a reciprocal intelligence
in all affaires
at should concerne
e religion and weale,
of his and their contreis: w
ch
was p
nt
ly obtained.
They were after sought unto, to renue
e ancient League,
at had bin in former times between Scotland and them:
wherunto they yealded by their Deputies, at
e tyme of
e
Baptesme of
e
young Prince
. Now thirdly, they are in-
treated to assist him with men
and
or
mony, whearof
e
su
m
e is so smal, not amounting to 8000
li
sterling for
3 monethes, as he might very well presume, that they
would not refuse him. And when this shalbe accorded,
whether it be not to be thought,
at he hath yet an inten-
tion, to geve some further footing in their love and affecti
o
,
and to serve some other turnes with their aide and support,
as his occasions shall require, and as it wilbe very easie,
when the people of these contreis are once engaged in his
actions, I leave it as
a
motion to yo
r
L. wisdome.
The Coronel pretendeth
at
e state of
e King must be p
nt
ly
relieved, and if it should be neglected by his frindes and
allies, it would engender ere be long some irreparable in-
convenience, both to him and to them, And this he doth
inculcat in every companie where he cometh, w
t
a fearefull
declaration of
e wantes of
e King and of
e strenght of
his Enemies: in soe much as
e States by
at as I can gather,
would willinglie doe for him, if my aunswear unto them
whereof your L. had notice, in one from me of
e 20 of
e
last, doe not stoppe their proceeding. For soe
e Coronel
hath tould me,
at he thought
e States resolution would de-
pend very much upon her
Hig
es
allowance, or onely upon me,
at if I would but signifie,
at her Hig
es
would be pleased
w
t
their aiding of the King, there would be no stoppe, and
he saw no just cause for me to be scrupulous, sith every
man might see the extremitie of
e King, and that part
fol.119r
of the benefit would redound unto her Ma
tie
and all the bur-
den of
e aide upon the people of these
Provinces.
I will not trouble your L. with long rehersall of my
answers and other speeches betweene us: but in effect they
were to pray him, to pardon my refusall, unles my warrant
were better. For said I, to speake of maters roundly and
famililarly between us, I may very well presume upon the
reasons you alleage,
at her Ma
tie
would be willing to
advance
e K. desyre, but yet it may be perhaps that she
will soe much mislike of his forme of proceeding, as she
would have
e States made acquainted with her manifold
endevors to free the K. of his troubles. Let it be as yow
give out,
at his State is reduced to pointes of extremitie,
wherof I know very little either one way or other (though
there be
at will avouch
at both his perill is not suche,
and
at it might have bin lesse, if he himself had listed)
howe can you reporte it heere, but they will p
nt
ly aske
e
question, why,
e King having soe largely and soe long
tasted of her Ma
ties
bountie, and the danger beyng neere
to England then to them, he should not rather in this
case, have recourse unto her Hig
es
, or at
e least make
her privie, and request her advise, before he sent to move
e States? In your answear heere unto I know not
how you will acquyte your selfe: but yow must without
offence give me leave to suspect,
at yow will speake very
little in her Ma
ties
behalf, but rather secretly complayne
in
e maneging of your businesse,
at she hath not, or will
not doe
e part of a neighbor, w
ch
may be soe amplified in
places where you come, as I doubt it may alsoe tende, to
worke some alienation in
e hartes of this people, from their
devotion to her Hig
es
. And these are suche suspitions,
or causes of suspitions, as they force me to forbeare, and not
to meddle of or on, unles I had co
m
ission. And therfore
onely as before, I wish
e States in these proposals, to hold a
sound correspondence by advising with her Hig
es
.
As a man touched neere and guiltie, as it seemed of some
sinister dealing (wherof I heare but to muche) he made a
frivolous replie, full of speeches as randon: w
ch
not beyng
worthie of your L. reading I leave unrehersed, very humbly
beseeching, that if you thincke it expedient, I may know
fol.119v
Copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r Ma
r
14 1594
D
r
Birch's Memoirs Vol Pag 219 [.]
by your direction, w
at
course I must observe, when I speake in
these affaires, to give her Ma
tie
good content.
I finde by a l
re
written by
e
F
r
King
to
Mons
r
Buzanval
at he hath sent her Ma
tie
certaine l
res
intercepted, w
ch
were written in cipher by
father Gordon
, and an other Scott
to their correspondence in
Spaine,
w
ch
e K. hath caused to
be deciphred. Gordon is one
at is often named in Cryttons
Latin l
re
, w
ch
I sent your L. last: and I should conjecture
at the notice of such a mater, as he hath written into
Spaine, may easilie laide to decipher
e l
res
of Crytton in
Latin: w
ch
if it be not done already, if your L. thincke
fitte to send me
e Copie of Gordons l
re
, and
e others, I will
doe my best endevor to discover
at of Crytton: which I doe
very much presume, upon certaine conjectures, containe
important mater, as
e conferring of some princely state
or dignitie, or contrey, upon some special person, upon whom
e chiefe hope of those fugitives dependeth: wherein it also
seemeth
at certaine great personages are nominated
actors:
And thus &c./.
